  "full_text": "# CRACKING ATTRIBUTION: MOVING INTERNATIONAL NORMS FORWARD\nJoshua Lefebvre\nThis Note addresses how international law can meet the challenge of reliably and transparently identifying the actor responsible for a cyber attack, a feature of the cyber landscape referred to as the “attribution problem.” It examines the potential for customary international law to define evidentiary standards for evaluating claims of a cyber attacker’s identity, standards which would have to be met before a state victim could retaliate. Such a framework would replace the malleable and opaque ad hoc determinations of responsibility that states currently undertake in both the conventional force and the cyber contexts alike. To this end, this Note introduces a sliding-scale evidentiary standard that adapts to the—often limited—availability of evidence and short amount of time a victim might have to respond to cyber attacks.\nThis Note analogizes to attribution problems faced by the international community in the past, such as piracy and privateering on the eighteenth century’s high seas, to demonstrate that the legal problems posed by cyber capabilities are not unfamiliar. But the ubiquity of cyber capabilities and diffuse nature of the cyber landscape mean that the solution must be different. This Note demonstrates that a newly proposed non-governmental attribution body, structured like a tribunal, could meet the tremendous need many victims face in gathering the evidence to overcome the attribution problem inherent to cyberspace. Such a body, this Note argues, provides the best launchpad for developing the international norms—and, eventually, the customary international law—needed to build evidentiary standards in the cyber context.\nINTRODUCTION ... 1\nI. Charter and core principles of customary international law, such as state sovereignty and non-intervention.¹¹\nThis Note begins in Part I by defining the attribution problem and identifying the factual challenges it poses for dealing with offensive cyber operations. It then explores the evidentiary framework by which attribution claims in both the conventional and cyber context are measured. In doing so, it attempts to identify and help fill the gap in the academic literature surrounding what standards of proof are and should be expected to be met under international law. Toward this end, it introduces a novel application of a sliding scale of proof, one tied to the severity of the victim’s response rather than solely to the underlying breach of international law. Part I then concludes by providing a brief overview of how principles of state responsibility apply in cyberspace.\nPart II identifies a number of the proposed solutions to the attribution problem suggested in the literature—such as intergovernmental inspection and compliance bodies as well as multilateral treaties—and explains why they are inadequate in the cyber context or are unlikely to come about. It then critiques and builds upon the solution highlighted by this Note: a non-governmental global consortium of representatives from private companies, academia, and think tanks that assesses available forensic evidence to provide an attributional assessment for victims of cyber attack or exploitation.¹² But the value of this organization does not just lie in its ability to provide a much-needed leader for neutral and capable technical investigations. And perhaps just as significant, the quality of the organization's attributional assessments carry great promise for their potential to shape state practice toward an expectation of higher quality attributional claims against other states.\nRather than have states judge for themselves how much proof is necessary to respond to an attack,¹³ this Note argues that states might feel obligated to justify their actions in the face of a quantifiable confidence metric, one that could be provided by the proposed non-governmental attribution body. Through reference to the attributional assessment of a neutral and sophisticated body, a state's self-defense¹⁴ and countermeasure¹⁵ activities could rest on a firmer and more transparent evidentiary foundation. In this way, this Note makes the novel suggestion that this non-governmental organization could serve as the best launchpad for developing customary international law to build evidentiary standards in the cyber context.\n## I. DEFINING THE ATTRIBUTION PROBLEM AND ITS SCOPE\nThe attribution problem is often viewed as a technical challenge with a technical solution: the tools of offensive cyber operations make it easy to hide one's identity from a victim, so would-be victims need to build cyber defensive capabilities and cyber forensic investigative capabilities to overcome this challenge. But the limitations of cyber defensive and investigative capabilities can and do pose obstacles to the application of international law. Principally, they foreground the question of how a state could respond lawfully under international law if it does not know against whom it should respond. Conventional Parallels\nThe difficulty in linking attacks to the identity of the attacker is not a new problem for international law: states have struggled with making such determinations for centuries. This is true where another state has been the attacker, where a non-state actor acting under its own direction has been the attacker, and where state proxies acting under the direction of a sponsoring state have been the source of the attacks. The Factual Challenge of Attribution\nAttribution of interstate cyber operations—like operations in the conventional kinetic context—can be broken down into two components: (1) the identity of the individual operators who carried out the operation; and (2) the relationship those operators have, if any, to any given state.⁴⁰ These two components comprise factual inquiries, of course, into what machines were used to carry out an attack, who operated them, and who directed or controlled those operators for purposes of the operation.\nAt the most basic level, an offensive cyber operation involves one or more individuals, often acting remotely, who interfaces with one or more computers or entire networks—usually by means of programming code—in order to gain access to the targeted systems through hardware or software security vulnerabilities or through fraudulent credentials. Once the operation’s conductors have gained access to the desired system, they attempt to take advantage of the system to plant code, known as malware,⁴¹ that will destroy or degrade the intruded system, exfiltrate information from the system, or both.⁴²\nCyber operations pose significant and unique challenges in the evidentiary context as it relates to both the identity of the operator and attribution to a state. This is in part because the operations are “opaque to public view, technically very complex and likely to emerge piecemeal,” unlike conventional kinetic attacks, which are visible and “can be and often are broadcast widely, immediately, and understandably [and, further, the] common experience [of such attacks] makes\n⁴⁰ See Military and Paramilitary Activities in and Against Nicaragua (Nicar. v. The first two relate to evidentiary standards for evaluating how much evidence a state must show and who, if any party, must bring forward that evidence. Is There an Attribution Standard for Cyberspace Under International Law?\nIn the cyber context, the answers to the evidentiary questions are even more underdeveloped due to the paucity of transparent state practice and *opinio juris*—a term that refers to a state’s sense of legal obligation—in making public attributional statements for offensive cyber operations.⁷⁶ In its 2015 report, the U.N. Group of Governmental Experts acknowledged that attribution claims for cyber operations “should be substantiated.” But the report failed to articulate how much or what type of evidence is necessary for states to justify countermeasures or acts of self-defense under international law, or even whether such claims must be substantiated publicly.⁷⁷ The United States has gone one step further in articulating its position on the matter in remarks made in November 2016 by then-U.S. Department of State Legal Adviser Brian Egan:\n⁷⁶ See Tallinn Manual 2.0, supra note 1, at 83. In this context, a State acts as its own judge of the facts and may make a unilateral determination with respect to attribution of a cyber operation to another State. Absolute certainty is not—and cannot be—required. Instead, international law generally requires that States act reasonably under the circumstances when they gather information and draw conclusions based on that information.78\nThe IGE understands this “reasonableness” standard as involving an examination of whether states have considered, among other factors, the reliability, quantum, directness, nature, and specificity of the relevant information available to the injured state in light of attendant circumstances and the importance of the right involved.79 While these factors are fairly malleable, the method is not dissimilar from the “ad hoc” way in which states evaluate factual claims in the conventional force context.80\nAs to whether the reasonableness standard includes the obligation to publicly disclose the evidence on which an attribution claim has been made, the IGE was of the opinion that there is not enough state practice or *opinio juris* to evidence such a requirement under customary international law.81 This insufficiency is, in large part, a result of the highly classified nature of cyber capabilities, whether used offensively, defensively, or as part of a forensic investigation.82 Conceivably, this could change as more forensic analysis of cyber operations is conducted by\n78 Brian J. Does International Law Already Contain a General Attribution Standard?\nDrawing from the above, it would seem that, at present, no state under international law carries an obligation of publicly proving its attributional claim by revealing the available evidence, whether that be in the cyber or conventional force context.⁸⁸ Nor does it seem that states carry a well-defined burden under international law related to the quality or amount of evidence used in proving an attributional claim before undertaking acts of self-defense or countermeasures against the accused state.⁸⁹ Further, strikingly few commentators have even addressed the issue of evidentiary burdens under international law. But despite the IGE’s findings and the claims that states like the United States have made about (non-)obligations under international law, there is a contingent of those few who have argued the contrary. Such commentators claim that sufficient state practice exists to locate the standard of proof required of attribution claims.⁹⁰\nProfessor Mary Ellen O’Connell has argued that, at least in situations in which states are justifying the use of force under Article 51’s self-defense provision, state practice and the decisions of international courts and tribunals support a “clear and convincing” standard in evaluating evidence.⁹¹ She claims that “the international authority for the standard consists of several\n⁸⁸ See also Banks, supra note 2, at 1499 (“Applying the Rules on State Responsibility and attribution compiled in Tallinn 2.0, there is no burden of proof or requirement that there exists definitive information on attribution. Charter); see Robin Geiß &amp; Henning Lahmann, Freedom and Security in Cyberspace: Shifting the Focus Away From Military Responses Towards Non-Forcible Countermeasures and Collective Threat-Prevention, in Peacetime Regime for State Activities in Cyberspace: International Law, International Relations and Diplomacy 621, 624 (Katharina Ziolkowski ed., 2013) (arguing that a “clear and convincing” standard has been applied in ICJ decisions governing state responsibility). Bush, and the 1998 bombing of Sudan and Afghanistan after attacks on U.S. embassies in Nairobi and Dar es Salaam.⁹² Professor O’Connell’s evidence for such claims raises questions, however, about whether such an obligation truly exists under international law.\nFirst, while she cites examples of state practice of injured states using language indicating that they are in possession of “clear,” “compelling,” or “convincing” evidence of having suffered an internationally wrongful act at the hand of a particular state, there is no indication that this is done out of a sense of legal obligation.⁹³ State practice on its own is insufficient to establish customary international law; it is only when it is done out of a sense of legal obligation, or *opinio juris*, that it can be considered customary international law. Further, the fact that she only cites U.S. practice draws into question whether one state’s practice is enough, even if the United States were acting out of a sense of legal obligation. Lastly, the United States and any number of other states have a multitude of political reasons to indicate that they are in possession of “clear” or “convincing” evidence. There is no suggestion that such states believe that this is an evidentiary floor that must be met under international law before they can act on the evidence in their possession.\n⁹² O’Connell, supra note 31, at 23–28.\n⁹³ But see Mark Landler &amp; Michael R. The ICJ’s opinion in the Nicaragua case, which these commentators claim supports a “clear and convincing” standard,⁹⁵ suggests that its standard of proof derives from Article 53 of the Statute on the International Court of Justice,⁹⁶ which does not purport to have impact outside of the operations of that court.⁹⁷ Further, O'Connell’s evidence that the ICJ uses a “clear and compelling” standard of proof is limited to consistent references to whether evidence is “sufficient” or “insufficient.”⁹⁸ But declaring whether a particular amount of evidence is sufficient is distinct from whether it is necessary. The Value of a Sliding-Scale Attribution Standard\nThe absence of a standard of proof in these matters may be surprising, but it is likely—at least in part—a reflection of the reluctance among nations to share closely guarded intelligence methods on a global stage in front of ally and adversary alike.¹⁰⁸ There is little doubt, however, that developing international norms to establish a standard of proof for attributional claims before undertaking countermeasures or self-defense measures would force states to exercise restraint in using these tools. One would hope that such restraint could help prevent conflicts from escalating or even spilling over into wrongly accused states that had no previous role in a particular conflict.¹⁰⁹ Problems arise, though, in determining how high such a standard should be for cyber operations, given the difficulty many states face in being able to make an attributional claim with a high degree of confidence in a short amount of time. Any standard of proof employed should be sufficiently flexible to allow a state to act quickly enough for its countermeasures to serve as an adequate means of forcing the offending state back into compliance with its international\n¹⁰⁷ See Statute of the International Court of Justice, June 26, 1945, art. 53(2), 59 Stat. 1055, 1062, T.S. No. 993.\n¹⁰⁸ The reluctance, of course, is not unfounded. Sharing intelligence with adversaries can better clue them into the methods of the victim state’s intelligence collection, helping adversaries to better identify their own security vulnerabilities. For one example of how providing intelligence can change an adversary’s behavior in a way that threatens a state’s national security, see Eric Schmitt &amp; Michael S. Such difficulty might be resolved by applying a shifting standard of proof, not unlike what the ICJ appears to employ based upon “the nature of the case.”\nA standard of proof tied to the anticipated severity of the victim state’s response rather than to the severity of the underlying breach might meet the goals of timely response while adapting to the lower quality and quantity of evidence available to the victim state shortly after suffering an offensive cyber operation.¹¹⁰ For example, the victim state might only need to find on the balance of evidence that a particular state is responsible for an offensive cyber operation if deploying countermeasures, such as the violation of a treaty between the victim and aggressor states, but it may need clear-and-convincing evidence to respond with a use of armed force. This proposal falls in line with the second Tallinn Manual’s suggestion that “the greater the underlying breach . . . the greater the confidence ought to be in the evidence relied upon by a State considering a response” since the “robustness of permissible self-help responses grows commensurately with the seriousness of the breach.”¹¹¹ For example, a state should be more confident in its attribution when it responds with armed force to a cyber attack on an air traffic control system that resulted in aircraft accidents and fatalities. The same should be expected if it were to suffer an attack on the underground pump controllers for an underground rail system that resulted in major flooding and destruction of its infrastructure. If a state were to suffer a denial of service attack on the website of a regulatory agency that issues permits for hunting and fishing, however, principles of necessity and proportionality dictate that the victim state would only be permitted to respond with something\n¹¹⁰ Professors Christian Payne and Lorraine Finlay have proposed a standard of proof tied to the victim’s response, but they have failed to provide much detail other than suggesting victim states that “pursue peaceful, legal processes” for resolving disputes related to cyber operations should “have the benefit of eschewing stringent attribution tests normally required.” Payne &amp; Finlay, supra note 5, at 567. In such cases, they suggest strict liability for those states that the victim state believes to be the host states for the attack. Id. at 566–67. They do not discuss the standard of proof necessary to undertake countermeasures and argue that the “effective control” standard is required for self-defense measures. Id.; see also infra note 132 and accompanying text (discussing the “effective control” standard).\n¹¹¹ Tallinn Manual 2.0, supra note 1, at 82 (citing Oil Platforms, 2003 I.C.J. at ¶ 67 (separate opinion of Judge Higgins)).\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202\nLefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n26\nbelow the use of force, such as committing a violation of a trade or tax treaty between the two states.¹¹²\nUnder a shifting standard of proof for attributional claims, a state could respond to the first two examples with countermeasures if it perhaps only had probable cause that a given state had conducted the attacks. After acquiring evidence to prove its attributional claim at a higher standard of proof, such as clear-and-convincing evidence, a state could respond with armed force if it were to conclude that such force would be proportional and necessary to repel the attack or later attacks.¹¹³ This shifting standard of proof does not change the ultimate severity ceiling of the response available to the victim state, which is still tied to the underlying breach and governed by principles of proportionality and necessity; rather, it adapts the severity of the response to the standard of proof that the victim state is able to meet at any given point.¹¹⁴ This would allow victim states to respond—at least in some fashion—more quickly, and thereby more effectively, to offensive cyber operations than if a higher evidentiary threshold were required uniformly among all types of responses. Victim states, of course, could still increase the severity of their responses as needed to force the attacking state back into compliance with its international obligations, so long as the certainty in the attacker’s identity correspondingly increased.\nAdmittedly, such a standard might result in more severe and more frequent state responses against less sophisticated actors—who lack the ability to hide the evidence that leads to their identity—than sophisticated actors. But this is no different than any other system that requires evidentiary burdens to be met before responsive measures can be taken: even in domestic criminal\n¹¹² See infra note 113.\n¹¹³ International Governmental Group of Experts, Tallinn Manual on the International Law Applicable to Cyber Warfare 61 (Michael N. Further, and more importantly, the proposed evidentiary framework will create opportunities for states to take measures against actors whose sophistication in hiding their identity would, under a more exacting standard of proof, leave victims without any recourse time and time again.\nPart II further explores how evaluations of such evidence could be more publicly accountable by allowing states to submit their claims to a neutral body that would provide an attributional assessment of the offensive cyber operation, including a forensic report and a confidence judgment as to the culprit. It also examines how such a body could contribute to the creation of international norms—and, eventually, customary international law—that integrate this sliding-scale evidentiary framework and which make it clear what standard of proof a state should have to meet before responding with the use of force or countermeasures. In this way, the body could create a platform through which states could better define customary international law, even where attempts to build positive international law have stalled or failed.^[115]^\n## D. Frameworks for Assessing State Responsibility for Cyber Operations\nIn contrast with standards of proof, principles of state responsibility are far better defined under international law, thanks to the ICJ's jurisprudence and the International Law Commission's (\"ILC\") Articles on State Responsibility. As a result, the second Tallinn Manual provides far more guidance about principles of state responsibility as they relate to cyber operations, beginning with Tallinn Rule 14's threshold^[116]^: \"A State bears international responsibility for a cyber-related act\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202\nLefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n28\nthat is attributable to the State and that constitutes a breach of an international legal obligation.”¹¹⁷ Rules 15–18 particularize this requirement by adapting it to common situations, with each rule further attenuating the relation from the responsible state. Rule 15 indicates that states are responsible for cyber operations conducted by their own organs and individual representatives of the state who are authorized to exercise the governmental authority of the state.¹¹⁸ Rule 16 addresses situations in which a state places one of its organs at the disposal of another state. It indicates that cyber operations are attributable to the latter state so long as it is exercising government authority over the former state’s organ.¹¹⁹ Rule 17 deals with state control of non-state actors. It identifies that the state is responsible for those cyber operations committed by non-state actors that it directs, controls, or that the state acknowledges and adopts as its own, reflecting the concept of “effective control” articulated in the Nicaragua case.¹²⁰ Rule 18 deals with a state’s responsibility for the cyber operations of foreign states, concluding that one state bears responsibility for another’s cyber operation when, knowing of the act’s wrongful character, it either coerces, aids or assists, or directs and controls that state in the operation.¹²¹ As a result of the distributed nature of the Internet, the second Tallinn Manual took the view that geography is of little importance into inquiries of state responsibility.¹²² Instead, the inquiry is almost entirely grounded in the instruction received and control exercised by any given state.¹²³\n¹¹⁷ Tallinn Manual 2.0, supra note 1, at 84. The language “breach of an international legal obligation” is particularly important, since it does not include activities that are either unregulated by international law, such as cyber espionage and related intelligence gathering, or are expressly permitted, such as suspension of international cyber communication services within its territory. Rep. at § 115).\n¹²¹ Id. at 100.\n¹²² Tallinn Manual 2.0, supra note 1, at 83.\n¹²³ Id.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202\nLefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n29\nAlternatively, a victim state could find that another state has violated principles of due diligence by not taking reasonable measures to prevent its territory or cyber infrastructure under its governmental control from being used by others to commit offensive cyber operations that either “affect the rights of or produce adverse consequences for other States,” an inquiry that necessarily involves geography.¹²⁴ In this case, which is governed by Rules 6–7 of the second Tallinn Manual, states would not be held responsible for such offensive cyber operations, but they would be held in breach of their obligation to exercise due diligence.¹²⁵ If the claim can be satisfactorily proven, this would allow the victim state to enact countermeasures in order to bring the negligent state back into compliance with its international obligations.¹²⁶\nWith the exception of Rules 6–7, each rule provides a separate avenue by which to attribute responsibility for a cyber operation to a particular state. While multilateral treaties and international cooperation might be the preferred avenue to overcome them, current trends provide little hope for the success of such options. Despite this, the development of customary international law provides an opportunity to push forward in regulating state behavior surrounding cyberspace. This Note demonstrates how an attributional body like the Consortium stands to provide substantial benefit to the development of these norms by providing states with a transparent and independent mechanism upon which to build evidentiary standards, such as the sliding-scale evidentiary framework, to undergird countermeasures and acts of self-defense. In this way, the international community can make more consistent judgments about state action in response to offensive cyber operations. While this may provide less flexibility for states to act in the face of such operations than what is nearly guaranteed through today's system of opaque unilateral evidentiary assessments, such restrictions on state behavior would benefit the international community at large by increasing global stability.   "flat_text": "# CRACKING ATTRIBUTION: MOVING INTERNATIONAL NORMS FORWARD\nJoshua Lefebvre\nThis Note addresses how international law can meet the challenge of reliably and transparently identifying the actor responsible for a cyber attack, a feature of the cyber landscape referred to as the “attribution problem.” It examines the potential for customary international law to define evidentiary standards for evaluating claims of a cyber attacker’s identity, standards which would have to be met before a state victim could retaliate. Such a framework would replace the malleable and opaque ad hoc determinations of responsibility that states currently undertake in both the conventional force and the cyber contexts alike. To this end, this Note introduces a sliding-scale evidentiary standard that adapts to the—often limited—availability of evidence and short amount of time a victim might have to respond to cyber attacks.\nThis Note analogizes to attribution problems faced by the international community in the past, such as piracy and privateering on the eighteenth century’s high seas, to demonstrate that the legal problems posed by cyber capabilities are not unfamiliar. But the ubiquity of cyber capabilities and diffuse nature of the cyber landscape mean that the solution must be different. This Note demonstrates that a newly proposed non-governmental attribution body, structured like a tribunal, could meet the tremendous need many victims face in gathering the evidence to overcome the attribution problem inherent to cyberspace. Such a body, this Note argues, provides the best launchpad for developing the international norms—and, eventually, the customary international law—needed to build evidentiary standards in the cyber context.\nINTRODUCTION ... 1\nI. Challenges Ahead ... 40\nCONCLUSION ... 45\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202\n# INTRODUCTION\nEach year, state and non-state cyber capabilities increase in sophistication while attack surfaces widen, and yet, international law has not kept pace. Treaties dealing directly with cyber operations are scarce in number and limited in scope. State cyber practices are held close to the chest and, although their publicly available expressions are increasing, there are still too few to constitute well-defined norms to develop comprehensive customary international law. While it at least seems clear today that existing principles of international law apply in cyberspace, states—perhaps as a result of their own strategic caution—have, at present, left to the academy and non-governmental bodies much of the task of determining how such principles apply. Against this hazy legal backdrop, states and non-state actors alike have wasted no time in deploying cyber attacks and exploitations of ever more destructive and exploitative power. In June 2017, according to the U.S. government, the Russian military launched “the most destructive and costly cyber attack in history,” using ransomware dubbed “NotPetya” to cause billions of dollars in damage across Europe, the Americas, and Asia. The Value of a Sliding-Scale Attribution Standard\nThe absence of a standard of proof in these matters may be surprising, but it is likely—at least in part—a reflection of the reluctance among nations to share closely guarded intelligence methods on a global stage in front of ally and adversary alike. There is little doubt, however, that developing international norms to establish a standard of proof for attributional claims before undertaking countermeasures or self-defense measures would force states to exercise restraint in using these tools. One would hope that such restraint could help prevent conflicts from escalating or even spilling over into wrongly accused states that had no previous role in a particular conflict. Problems arise, though, in determining how high such a standard should be for cyber operations, given the difficulty many states face in being able to make an attributional claim with a high degree of confidence in a short amount of time. Charter, limiting it to a victim state’s uses of force taken against an aggressor state in response to an armed attack. U.N. Charter, art. 51.\n¹⁵ In this Note, the term “countermeasures” is used as a term of art. Conventional Parallels": "The difficulty in linking attacks to the identity of the attacker is not a new problem for international law: states have struggled with making such determinations for centuries. This is true where another state has been the attacker, where a non-state actor acting under its own direction has been the attacker, and where state proxies acting under the direction of a sponsoring state have been the source of the attacks. Some commentators have drawn parallels between today’s challenges in policing cyberspace to those created by the state use of privateers on the high seas in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.²⁴ Florian Egloff notes how both the high seas through that period and cyberspace involve a range of actors, each with varying degrees of direction and control from a sponsoring state.²⁵ Between these two different eras and environments, the parallels between state actors, semi-state actors, and non-state actors can be readily drawn: respectively, consider the similarities between formal navies and cyber military units, privateers and today’s “patriotic hackers,”²⁶ or even pirates and most modern cybercriminals or cybercrime organizations.²⁷\n²³ See infra note 66.\n²⁴ Florian Egloff, Cybersecurity and the Age of Privateering, in Understanding Cyber Conflict: 14 Analogies 231, (George Perkovich &amp; Ariel E. Levite eds., 2017); Noah Schachtman &amp; Peter W. Singer, The Wrong War: The Insistence on Applying Cold War Metaphors to Cybersecurity is Misplaced and Counterproductive, Brookings (August 15, 2011), https://www.brookings.edu/articles/the-wrong-war-the-insistence-on-applying-cold-war-metaphors-to-cybersecurity-is-misplaced-and-counterproductive/.\n²⁵ Florian Egloff, Cybersecurity and the Ague of Privateering, in Understanding Cyber Conflict: 14 Analogies, supra note 24, at 238–39.\n²⁶ The term “patriotic hackers” is a reference to Russian President Vladimir Putin’s suggestion that “patriotically minded” private Russian hackers, but not the Russian government or its organs, could have been the operators behind the 2016 cyber exploitation of the U.S. Democratic National Committee’s servers. Andrew Higgins, Maybe Private Russian Hackers Meddled in Election, Putin Says, N.Y. Times (June 1, 2017), https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/01/world/europe/vladimir-putin-donald-trump-hacking.html.\n²⁷ Id.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202\nLefebvre\nCracking Attribution\nMore modern comparisons are often drawn to the Cold War, where attribution and causality issues frequently arose in the context of Article 2(4) of the U.N. Charter’s prohibition on the use of force.³² This came about in large part from the transition from conventional war-making to “unconventional [and] low-intensity conflict [that] featured inconclusive evidence of foreign involvement or hostile action, and foreign state antagonists [who] worked to mask, conceal, or obscure their participation and responses.”³³ As with today’s cyber attacks and exploitations, “once ²⁸ Carl J. Kulsrud, Maritime Neutrality to 1780 158 (1936); Janice E. Thomson, Explaining the Regulation of Transnational Practices: A State-Building Approach, in Governance Without Government: Order and Change in World Politics 195, 203 (James N. Roseau &amp; Ernst-Otto Czempiel eds., 1992); Peter W. Singer and Allan Friedman, What Can (Real) Pirates Teach Us About Cybersecurity?, Slate: Future Tense (Jan. 1 2014, 11:45 PM), http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/future_tense/2014/01/cybersecurity_and_cyberwar_excerpt_what_real_pirates_can_teach_us.html.\n²⁹ See Foreign Cyber Threats to the United States: Hearing Before the S. Armed Servs. Comm., 115th Cong. 8 (2017) (statement of Jack Reed, U.S. Senator from Rhode Island) (suggesting that because detection and attribution of the attacks on the Democratic National Committee were not very difficult, it leads to the inference that Russia only wanted enough plausible deniability to support “an official rejection of culpability”).\n³⁰ See Kulsrud, supra note 28, at 158.\n³¹ Gary M. While technical attribution capabilities are increasing for many states, including the United States, the identification of the machine or machines used in carrying out the attack, their operators, or even the geographic locations of the machines and their operators is not always enough when making a determination of state responsibility.³⁶ Yet the stakes are high. Challenges Ahead": "Despite the promise an independent non-governmental attribution body like the Consortium holds for building international norms, challenges remain for the Consortium’s effective execution. If independence is a key feature, from what sources could it responsibly derive funding? How will such a body prioritize its investigations and how will it deliver results quickly enough to meet the need for timely response that victim states will face? The Value of a Sliding-Scale Attribution Standard\nThe absence of a standard of proof in these matters may be surprising, but it is likely—at least in part—a reflection of the reluctance among nations to share closely guarded intelligence methods on a global stage in front of ally and adversary alike. There is little doubt, however, that developing international norms to establish a standard of proof for attributional claims before undertaking countermeasures or self-defense measures would force states to exercise restraint in using these tools. One would hope that such restraint could help prevent conflicts from escalating or even spilling over into wrongly accused states that had no previous role in a particular conflict. Problems arise, though, in determining how high such a standard should be for cyber operations, given the difficulty many states face in being able to make an attributional claim with a high degree of confidence in a short amount of time. Any standard of proof employed should be sufficiently flexible to allow a state to act quickly enough for its countermeasures to serve as an adequate means of forcing the offending state back into compliance with its international\n See Statute of the International Court of Justice, June 26, 1945, art. 53(2), 59 Stat. 1055, 1062, T.S. No. 993.\n The reluctance, of course, is not unfounded. Sharing intelligence with adversaries can better clue them into the methods of the victim state’s intelligence collection, helping adversaries to better identify their own security vulnerabilities. For one example of how providing intelligence can change an adversary’s behavior in a way that threatens a state’s national security, see Eric Schmitt &amp; Michael S. A/66/152 (July 15, 2011) (reply received from the United States) (“The lack of timely, high-confidence attribution and the possibility of ‘spoofing’ can create uncertainty and confusion for Governments, thus increasing the potential for crisis instability, misdirected responses and loss of escalation control during major cyberincidents.”).\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202\nLefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n\nA standard of proof tied to the anticipated severity of the victim state’s response rather than to the severity of the underlying breach might meet the goals of timely response while adapting to the lower quality and quantity of evidence available to the victim state shortly after suffering an offensive cyber operation. For example, the victim state might only need to find on the balance of evidence that a particular state is responsible for an offensive cyber operation if deploying countermeasures, such as the violation of a treaty between the victim and aggressor states, but it may need clear-and-convincing evidence to respond with a use of armed force. This proposal falls in line with the second Tallinn Manual’s suggestion that “the greater the underlying breach . . . the greater the confidence ought to be in the evidence relied upon by a State considering a response” since the “robustness of permissible self-help responses grows commensurately with the seriousness of the breach.” For example, a state should be more confident in its attribution when it responds with armed force to a cyber attack on an air traffic control system that resulted in aircraft accidents and fatalities. While the accord is still young, its existence is a helpful indication of the tech sector’s thinking on these issues, and it suggests that the possibility of an investigative body like the Consortium is more greater than it appears on its face.\n Brad Smith Takes His Call for a Digital Geneva Convention to the United Nations, Microsoft: Microsoft On the Issues (Nov. 7, 2017), https://blogs.microsoft.com/on-the-issues/2017/11/09/brad-smith-takes-call-digital-geneva-convention-united-nations/.\n Sam Meredith, Microsoft Calls for ‘New Digital Geneva Convention’ after Spate of High-Profile Cyberattacks, CNBC (Jan. 26, 2018), https://www.cnbc.com/2018/01/26/microsoft-calls-for-new-digital-geneva-convention-after-spate-of-high-profile-cyberattacks.html\n Brad Smith, The Need for a Digital Geneva Convention, Microsoft: Microsoft on the Issues (Feb. 14, 2017), https://blogs.microsoft.com/on-the-issues/2017/02/14/need-digital-geneva-convention/#sm.0001hkfw5aob5evwum620jqwsabzv.\n David Sanger, Tech Firms Sign “Digital Geneva Accord” Not to Aid Governments in Cyberwar, N.Y. Times (April 17, 2018), https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/17/us/politics/tech-companies-cybersecurity-accord.html; About the Cybersecurity Tech Accord, Cybersecurity Tech Accord, https://cybertechaccord.org/about/ (last visited March 29, 2019).\n Protecting Users and Customers Everywhere, Cybersecurity Tech Accords: Our Commitment, https://cybertechaccord.org/accord/ (last visited March 29, 2019).\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202\nLefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n\nChallenges dot the road ahead for progress on international norms in cyberspace. While multilateral treaties and international cooperation might be the preferred avenue to overcome them, current trends provide little hope for the success of such options. Despite this, the development of customary international law provides an opportunity to push forward in regulating state behavior surrounding cyberspace. This Note demonstrates how an attributional body like the Consortium stands to provide substantial benefit to the development of these norms by providing states with a transparent and independent mechanism upon which to build evidentiary standards, such as the sliding-scale evidentiary framework, to undergird countermeasures and acts of self-defense. In this way, the international community can make more consistent judgments about state action in response to offensive cyber operations. While this may provide less flexibility for states to act in the face of such operations than what is nearly guaranteed through today's system of opaque unilateral evidentiary assessments, such restrictions on state behavior would benefit the international community at large by increasing global stability. Further, adopting this Note's version of a sliding-scale approach to the standard of proof—one where the standard fluctuates based on the response a victim wishes to undertake—should accommodate the flexibility states need when attempting to respond to quickly to a cyber attack.\nBy offering both victim states and the accused the opportunity to obtain an independent, sophisticated, and quantifiable attributional assessment, a body like the Consortium could help alleviate the deterrence difficulties inherent in a low-confidence attribution landscape and reduce the risk that states escalate or begin conflicts with parties that have no relation to the conflict. Questions persist regarding sources of funding for the Consortium, its operational efficiency in light of the need for quick responses to severe offensive operations, and the remaining difficulty\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202\nLefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n\nWhatever the case, the world will not stand still in the cyber landscape. If international law is to be of any value in restricting dangerous state behavior in this arena, its development must push forward. States can still do their part to gradually advance international norms by responsibly conducting their own cyber practices and related behavior in an effort to shape customary international law. An independent non-governmental attributional body like the Consortium provides a powerful launchpad for them to do just that.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202",

Bush, and the 1998 bombing of Sudan and Afghanistan after attacks on U.S. embassies in Nairobi and Dar es Salaam.⁹² Professor O’Connell’s evidence for such claims raises questions, however, about whether such an obligation truly exists under international law.",

          "index": 22,
          "intext_citation": "²²",
          "preceding_text": "",
          "footnote": "While Professor O'Connell and other commentators cite implicit standards of proof in the International Court of Justice’s (“ICJ”) rulings, among other international courts and tribunals,⁹⁴ there is no indication that the ICJ’s procedural standards have any bearing on claims that appear in front of other bodies or that such standards reflect customary international law. The ICJ’s opinion in the Nicaragua case, which these commentators claim supports a “clear and convincing” standard,⁹⁵ suggests that its standard of proof derives from Article 53 of the Statute on the International Court of Justice,⁹⁶ which does not purport to have impact outside of the operations of that court.⁹⁷ Further, O'Connell’s evidence that the ICJ uses a “clear and compelling” standard of proof is limited to consistent references to whether evidence is “sufficient” or “insufficient.”⁹⁸ But declaring whether a particular amount of evidence is sufficient is distinct from whether it is necessary. Indeed, the ICJ’s opinion merely points to the fact that evidence has met or surpassed the necessary standard of proof; it does not indicate what that standard is. While the ICJ does mention that its findings of fact should be based upon “convincing” evidence, it includes a caveat: that it should only do so to the extent that “the nature of the case permits.”⁹⁹ This seems to suggest a shifting standard of proof, determined on the basis of the availability and nature of the facts.",

          "footnote": "While Professor O'Connell and other commentators cite implicit standards of proof in the International Court of Justice’s (“ICJ”) rulings, among other international courts and tribunals,⁹⁴ there is no indication that the ICJ’s procedural standards have any bearing on claims that appear in front of other bodies or that such standards reflect customary international law. The ICJ’s opinion in the Nicaragua case, which these commentators claim supports a “clear and convincing” standard,⁹⁵ suggests that its standard of proof derives from Article 53 of the Statute on the International Court of Justice,⁹⁶ which does not purport to have impact outside of the operations of that court.⁹⁷ Further, O'Connell’s evidence that the ICJ uses a “clear and compelling” standard of proof is limited to consistent references to whether evidence is “sufficient” or “insufficient.”⁹⁸ But declaring whether a particular amount of evidence is sufficient is distinct from whether it is necessary. Indeed, the ICJ’s opinion merely points to the fact that evidence has met or surpassed the necessary standard of proof; it does not indicate what that standard is. While the ICJ does mention that its findings of fact should be based upon “convincing” evidence, it includes a caveat: that it should only do so to the extent that “the nature of the case permits.”⁹⁹ This seems to suggest a shifting standard of proof, determined on the basis of the availability and nature of the facts.",

          "intext_citation": "³⁶",
          "preceding_text": "",
          "footnote": "More complex issues arise when deciding which of multiple states should have standing to bring a claim. Consider, for example, a scenario in which an actor conducts an offensive cyber operation against a company incorporated in the United States with its principal place of business in the United States. Suppose, however, that the company also has offices in Beijing and the offensive cyber operation was conducted exclusively against the company’s servers in Beijing, resulting in significant physical destruction of company property and the death of one or more U.S. nationals. On one hand, one might think that the United States is the victim state, since a kinetic attack was conducted against its nationals and their property.¹⁵⁶ However, if the culprit is a foreign state, China would have suffered an armed attack and a violation of its territorial integrity.¹⁵⁷ But depending on the circumstances surrounding the attack, there might even be reasonable suspicion that China itself is the culprit. Which state should be able to bring the episode to the Consortium? The answer, at least on these facts, seems to be that both states should have standing to bring the investigation request. But even if both parties have standing, should both enjoy the right to publicize the result? If the United States wanted to publicize the result, but China did not, should China retain a veto over the United States’ decision to publicize? The answer to that question is unclear, but it demonstrates that standing to bring an investigation request may not necessarily track with the right to publicize the result. It would seem prudent, despite the international relations costs, for the Consortium to tie standing with the exclusive right to publicize the results: divvying",

          "footnote": "While forensic analyses can assess the sophistication levels of threat actors and can support inferences about state involvement based on the sophistication of the attack, making state responsibility claims will be difficult, especially if states begin to contract out more and more offensive cyber operations to non-state actors.¹⁷³ Associating state control with offensive cyber operations is not impossible, however, and to date private cybersecurity firms have been able to find enough clues to make at least low- or medium-confidence assessments of state responsibility.           "preceding_text": " as nearly any other actor of\n",
          "footnote": "While forensic analyses can assess the sophistication levels of threat actors and can support inferences about state involvement based on the sophistication of the attack, making state responsibility claims will be difficult, especially if states begin to contract out more and more offensive cyber operations to non-state actors.¹⁷³ Associating state control with offensive cyber operations is not impossible, however, and to date private cybersecurity firms have been able to find enough clues to make at least low- or medium-confidence assessments of state responsibility. In 2013, Mandiant felt confident enough to attach blame to a Chinese military unit for numerous attacks on U.S. corporations, organizations, and government agencies.¹⁷⁴ And FireEye has compiled enough evidence to confidently connect a threat it refers to as “APT37,” or “Reaper,” with the North Korean state.¹⁷⁵ While this is an area where traditional intelligence capabilities will still be critical to attribution investigations, the Consortium’s work can help bolster claims of state responsibility made by states based on classified evidence, even if the Consortium’s findings are less conclusive than evidence the victim state might possess.",
          "position": 33403

      "flat_text": "# CRACKING ATTRIBUTION: MOVING INTERNATIONAL NORMS FORWARD\nJoshua Lefebvre\nThis Note addresses how international law can meet the challenge of reliably and transparently identifying the actor responsible for a cyber attack, a feature of the cyber landscape referred to as the “attribution problem.” It examines the potential for customary international law to define evidentiary standards for evaluating claims of a cyber attacker’s identity, standards which would have to be met before a state victim could retaliate. Such a framework would replace the malleable and opaque ad hoc determinations of responsibility that states currently undertake in both the conventional force and the cyber contexts alike. To this end, this Note introduces a sliding-scale evidentiary standard that adapts to the—often limited—availability of evidence and short amount of time a victim might have to respond to cyber attacks.\nThis Note analogizes to attribution problems faced by the international community in the past, such as piracy and privateering on the eighteenth century’s high seas, to demonstrate that the legal problems posed by cyber capabilities are not unfamiliar. But the ubiquity of cyber capabilities and diffuse nature of the cyber landscape mean that the solution must be different. This Note demonstrates that a newly proposed non-governmental attribution body, structured like a tribunal, could meet the tremendous need many victims face in gathering the evidence to overcome the attribution problem inherent to cyberspace. Such a body, this Note argues, provides the best launchpad for developing the international norms—and, eventually, the customary international law—needed to build evidentiary standards in the cyber context.\nINTRODUCTION ... 1\nI. DEFINING THE ATTRIBUTION PROBLEM AND ITS SCOPE ... 4\nA. Conventional Parallels ... 7\nB. The Factual Challenge of Attribution ... 10\n1. Sources of Information for Attribution Assessments ... 12\nC. Locating Evidentiary Standards for State Breaches of International Obligations ... 15\n1. Is There an Attribution Standard for Cyberspace Under International Law? ... 17\n2. Does International Law Already Contain a General Attribution Standard? ... 20\n3. The Value of a Sliding-Scale Attribution Standard ... 24\nD. Frameworks for Assessing State Responsibility for Cyber Operations ... 27\nII. MOVING TOWARD A GLOBAL CONSORTIUM ... 29\nA. Building a Private Body for a Public Good ... 32\nB. Filling the Evidentiary Gap and Building International Norms ... 38\nC. Challenges Ahead ... 40\nCONCLUSION ... 45\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202\n# INTRODUCTION\nEach year, state and non-state cyber capabilities increase in sophistication while attack surfaces widen, and yet, international law has not kept pace. Treaties dealing directly with cyber operations are scarce in number and limited in scope. State cyber practices are held close to the chest and, although their publicly available expressions are increasing, there are still too few to constitute well-defined norms to develop comprehensive customary international law. While it at least seems clear today that existing principles of international law apply in cyberspace, states—perhaps as a result of their own strategic caution—have, at present, left to the academy and non-governmental bodies much of the task of determining how such principles apply. Against this hazy legal backdrop, states and non-state actors alike have wasted no time in deploying cyber attacks and exploitations of ever more destructive and exploitative power. In June 2017, according to the U.S. government, the Russian military launched “the most destructive and costly cyber attack in history,” using ransomware dubbed “NotPetya” to cause billions of dollars in damage across Europe, the Americas, and Asia. Just two months later, in August 2017, a petrochemical plant in Saudi Arabia suffered a cyber attack that was designed to trigger an explosion that likely\n Introduction to International Governmental Group of Experts, Tallinn Manual 2.0 on the International Law Applicable to Cyber Operations 3 (Michael N. Schmitt ed., 2d ed. 2017) [hereinafter Tallinn Manual 2.0].\n Id.; William Banks, Symposium, State Responsibility and Attribution of Cyber Intrusions After Tallinn 2.0, 95 Tex. L. Rev. 1487, 1494 (2017).\n Rep. of the Group of Governmental Experts on Devs. in the Field of Info. and Telecomms. in the Context of Int'l Security, transmitted by Letter Dated 7 June 2013 from Deborah Stokes (Chair of the Group), U.N. Doc. A/68/98 at 2 (June 24, 2013) (“The report reflects the Group’s conclusion that international law and in particular the United Nations Charter, is applicable and is essential to maintaining peace and stability and promoting an open, secure, and peaceful and accessible [information and communication technologies (“ICT”)] environment. The Group also concluded that State sovereignty and the international principles that flow from it apply to States’ conduct of ICT-related activities and to their jurisdiction over ICT infrastructure with their territory; States must meet their international obligations regarding internationally wrongful acts attributable to them.”).\n See Matthew C. Waxman, Cyber-Attacks and the Use of Force: Back to the Future of Article 2(4), 36 Yale J. Int'l L. 421, 434 n. 37, 453, 456 (2011).\n Christian Payne &amp; Lorraine Finlay, Addressing Obstacles to Cyber-Attribution: A Model Based on State Response to Cyber-Attack, 49 Geo. Wash. Int'l L. Rev. 535, 536 (2017).\n Press Release, The White House, Statement from the Press Secretary (Feb. 15, 2018), https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefings-statements/statement-press-secretary-25/.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202\nLefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n\nTo be sure, monumental accomplishments have been made in identifying how international law applies in the cyber arena, and the academy has extensively explored the difficult questions that arise from their application, or lack thereof. Most notably, the first and second Tallinn Manual on the International Law Applicable to Cyber Operations, written by the International Group of Experts (“IGE”), have proven to be influential in detailing how international principles apply to cyberspace and, in particular, their application to cyber warfare. But even where consensus can be built around which principles of international law apply to cyberspace, a key roadblock remains toward much of their implementation. Namely, the application of state responsibility principles remains difficult—if not impossible—where victims cannot reliably and transparently identify the actor responsible or, worse, if the attacker’s identity remains unknown. This “attribution problem”\n Nicole Perlroth &amp; Clifford Krauss, A Cyberattack in Saudi Arabia Had a Deadly Goal. Experts Fear Another Try., N.Y. Times (March 15, 2018), https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/15/technology/saudi-arabia-hacks-cyberattacks.html.\n See, e.g., Duncan B. Hollis, Why States Need an International Law for Information Operations, 11 Lewis &amp; Clark L. Rev. 1023 (2007); Eric Talbot Jensen, Computer Attacks on Critical National Infrastructure: A Use of Force Invoking the Right of Self-Defense, 38 Stan. J. Int’l L. 207 (2002); Michael N. Schmitt, Computer Network Attack and the Use of Force in International Law: Thoughts on a Normative Framework, 37 Colum. J. Transnat’l L. 885 (1999); Sean Watts, Low-Intensity Computer Network Attack and Self-Defense, 87 Int’l L. Studs. 59 (2011).\n International Governmental Group of Experts, Tallinn Manual on the International Law Applicable to Cyber Operations (Michael N. Schmitt ed., 2013) [hereinafter Tallinn Manual 1.0]; Tallinn Manual 2.0, supra note 1. The Tallinn Manuals are not international agreements and do not generate any law in their own right. Despite being commissioned by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, they are neither state-led nor an official NATO project. Brian J. Egan, Remarks on International Law and Stability in Cyberspace at Berkeley Law School (Nov. 10, 2016), https://www.law.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/egan-talk-transcript-111016.pdf. Nevertheless, as restatements on international law that describe how the law as it is today applies in the cyber context, they have still proven influential. Michael J. Adams, A Warning About Tallinn 2.0 . . . Whatever it Says, Lawfare (Jan. 4, 2017, 8:30 AM), https://www.lawfareblog.com/warning-about-tallinn-20-...-whatever-it-says (highlighting that the first Tallinn Manual is “routinely referenced and relied upon by civilian and military practitioners across the globe” and is or will be considered “one of the authoritative manuals detailing the manner in which international law applies to particular forms of warfare”); Amber Corrin, What Does International Law Mean for Cyber Warfare?, Federal Computer Week (April 2, 2013), https://fccw.com/articles/2013/04/02/cyber-engagement-international-law.aspx (noting that the first Tallinn Manual supplemented the U.S. Department of Defense’s cyber warfare guidelines); Egan, supra (expressing that the Tallinn Manual project is a “valuable contribution to underscoring and demonstrating [how international law applies to state behavior cyberspace] across a number of bodies of international law”). But see Dan Efrony &amp; Yuval Shany, A Rule Book on The Shelf? Tallinn Manual 2.0 on Cyber Operations and Subsequent State Practice, (Hebrew Univ. of Jerusalem L. Research Paper No. 18-22, 2018), https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3172743 (finding that the Tallinn Manuals have not had a significant impact on state practice and opinio juris after an analysis of the major cyber incidents taking place in the preceding five years).\n A brief explanation of the status of the law of state responsibility and its modern origin is provided at infra note 18.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202\nLefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n\nThis Note begins in Part I by defining the attribution problem and identifying the factual challenges it poses for dealing with offensive cyber operations. It then explores the evidentiary framework by which attribution claims in both the conventional and cyber context are measured. In doing so, it attempts to identify and help fill the gap in the academic literature surrounding what standards of proof are and should be expected to be met under international law. Toward this end, it introduces a novel application of a sliding scale of proof, one tied to the severity of the victim’s response rather than solely to the underlying breach of international law. Part I then concludes by providing a brief overview of how principles of state responsibility apply in cyberspace.\nPart II identifies a number of the proposed solutions to the attribution problem suggested in the literature—such as intergovernmental inspection and compliance bodies as well as multilateral treaties—and explains why they are inadequate in the cyber context or are unlikely to come about. It then critiques and builds upon the solution highlighted by this Note: a non-governmental global consortium of representatives from private companies, academia, and think tanks that assesses available forensic evidence to provide an attributional assessment for victims of cyber attack or exploitation. But the value of this organization does not just lie in its ability to provide a much-needed leader for neutral and capable technical investigations. Rather, it has significant potential to lay the groundwork for the proposed sliding-scale evidentiary framework’s\n See Waxman, supra note 4, at 426.\n While this Note recognizes the benefits of solutions that propose an intergovernmental organization to govern cyber capability use and compliance, akin to the International Atomic Energy Agency (“IAEA”), see, e.g., Scott Charney et al., Microsoft Corp., From Articulation to Implementation: Enabling Progress on Cybersecurity Norms 11 (2016), it also recognizes that states are highly unlikely in today’s toxic geopolitical environment to agree to allow representatives from foreign governments to inspect some of their most closely held secrets. Further, significant doubts might arise as to the neutrality of governmental representatives serving in the body’s management and operational roles, risking the legitimacy and independence of the body’s assessments.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202\nLefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n\nRather than have states judge for themselves how much proof is necessary to respond to an attack, this Note argues that states might feel obligated to justify their actions in the face of a quantifiable confidence metric, one that could be provided by the proposed non-governmental attribution body. Through reference to the attributional assessment of a neutral and sophisticated body, a state's self-defense and countermeasure activities could rest on a firmer and more transparent evidentiary foundation. In this way, this Note makes the novel suggestion that this non-governmental organization could serve as the best launchpad for developing customary international law to build evidentiary standards in the cyber context.\n## I. DEFINING THE ATTRIBUTION PROBLEM AND ITS SCOPE\nThe attribution problem is often viewed as a technical challenge with a technical solution: the tools of offensive cyber operations make it easy to hide one's identity from a victim, so would-be victims need to build cyber defensive capabilities and cyber forensic investigative capabilities to overcome this challenge. But the limitations of cyber defensive and investigative capabilities can and do pose obstacles to the application of international law. Principally, they foreground the question of how a state could respond lawfully under international law if it does not know against whom it should respond. Conventional Parallels\nThe difficulty in linking attacks to the identity of the attacker is not a new problem for international law: states have struggled with making such determinations for centuries. This is true where another state has been the attacker, where a non-state actor acting under its own direction has been the attacker, and where state proxies acting under the direction of a sponsoring state have been the source of the attacks. Some commentators have drawn parallels between today’s challenges in policing cyberspace to those created by the state use of privateers on the high seas in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. Florian Egloff notes how both the high seas through that period and cyberspace involve a range of actors, each with varying degrees of direction and control from a sponsoring state. Conventional Parallels\nThe difficulty in linking attacks to the identity of the attacker is not a new problem for international law: states have struggled with making such determinations for centuries. This is true where another state has been the attacker, where a non-state actor acting under its own direction has been the attacker, and where state proxies acting under the direction of a sponsoring state have been the source of the attacks. Some commentators have drawn parallels between today’s challenges in policing cyberspace to those created by the state use of privateers on the high seas in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.²⁴ Florian Egloff notes how both the high seas through that period and cyberspace involve a range of actors, each with varying degrees of direction and control from a sponsoring state.²⁵ Between these two different eras and environments, the parallels between state actors, semi-state actors, and non-state actors can be readily drawn: respectively, consider the similarities between formal navies and cyber military units, privateers and today’s “patriotic hackers,”²⁶ or even pirates and most modern cybercriminals or cybercrime organizations.²⁷\n²³ See infra note 66.\n²⁴ Florian Egloff, Cybersecurity and the Age of Privateering, in Understanding Cyber Conflict: 14 Analogies 231, (George Perkovich &amp; Ariel E. The Factual Challenge of Attribution\nAttribution of interstate cyber operations—like operations in the conventional kinetic context—can be broken down into two components: (1) the identity of the individual operators who carried out the operation; and (2) the relationship those operators have, if any, to any given state.⁴⁰ These two components comprise factual inquiries, of course, into what machines were used to carry out an attack, who operated them, and who directed or controlled those operators for purposes of the operation.\nAt the most basic level, an offensive cyber operation involves one or more individuals, often acting remotely, who interfaces with one or more computers or entire networks—usually by means of programming code—in order to gain access to the targeted systems through hardware or software security vulnerabilities or through fraudulent credentials. Once the operation’s conductors have gained access to the desired system, they attempt to take advantage of the system to plant code, known as malware,⁴¹ that will destroy or degrade the intruded system, exfiltrate information from the system, or both.⁴²\nCyber operations pose significant and unique challenges in the evidentiary context as it relates to both the identity of the operator and attribution to a state. This is in part because the operations are “opaque to public view, technically very complex and likely to emerge piecemeal,” unlike conventional kinetic attacks, which are visible and “can be and often are broadcast widely, immediately, and understandably [and, further, the] common experience [of such attacks] makes\n⁴⁰ See Military and Paramilitary Activities in and Against Nicaragua (Nicar. v. Does International Law Already Contain a General Attribution Standard?\nDrawing from the above, it would seem that, at present, no state under international law carries an obligation of publicly proving its attributional claim by revealing the available evidence, whether that be in the cyber or conventional force context.⁸⁸ Nor does it seem that states carry a well-defined burden under international law related to the quality or amount of evidence used in proving an attributional claim before undertaking acts of self-defense or countermeasures against the accused state.⁸⁹ Further, strikingly few commentators have even addressed the issue of evidentiary burdens under international law. But despite the IGE’s findings and the claims that states like the United States have made about (non-)obligations under international law, there is a contingent of those few who have argued the contrary. Bush, and the 1998 bombing of Sudan and Afghanistan after attacks on U.S. embassies in Nairobi and Dar es Salaam.⁹² Professor O’Connell’s evidence for such claims raises questions, however, about whether such an obligation truly exists under international law.\nFirst, while she cites examples of state practice of injured states using language indicating that they are in possession of “clear,” “compelling,” or “convincing” evidence of having suffered an internationally wrongful act at the hand of a particular state, there is no indication that this is done out of a sense of legal obligation.⁹³ State practice on its own is insufficient to establish customary international law; it is only when it is done out of a sense of legal obligation, or *opinio juris*, that it can be considered customary international law. The Value of a Sliding-Scale Attribution Standard\nThe absence of a standard of proof in these matters may be surprising, but it is likely—at least in part—a reflection of the reluctance among nations to share closely guarded intelligence methods on a global stage in front of ally and adversary alike.¹⁰⁸ There is little doubt, however, that developing international norms to establish a standard of proof for attributional claims before undertaking countermeasures or self-defense measures would force states to exercise restraint in using these tools. One would hope that such restraint could help prevent conflicts from escalating or even spilling over into wrongly accused states that had no previous role in a particular conflict.¹⁰⁹ Problems arise, though, in determining how high such a standard should be for cyber operations, given the difficulty many states face in being able to make an attributional claim with a high degree of confidence in a short amount of time. Any standard of proof employed should be sufficiently flexible to allow a state to act quickly enough for its countermeasures to serve as an adequate means of forcing the offending state back into compliance with its international\n¹⁰⁷ See Statute of the International Court of Justice, June 26, 1945, art. 53(2), 59 Stat. 1055, 1062, T.S. Such difficulty might be resolved by applying a shifting standard of proof, not unlike what the ICJ appears to employ based upon “the nature of the case.”\nA standard of proof tied to the anticipated severity of the victim state’s response rather than to the severity of the underlying breach might meet the goals of timely response while adapting to the lower quality and quantity of evidence available to the victim state shortly after suffering an offensive cyber operation.¹¹⁰ For example, the victim state might only need to find on the balance of evidence that a particular state is responsible for an offensive cyber operation if deploying countermeasures, such as the violation of a treaty between the victim and aggressor states, but it may need clear-and-convincing evidence to respond with a use of armed force. This proposal falls in line with the second Tallinn Manual’s suggestion that “the greater the underlying breach . . . the greater the confidence ought to be in the evidence relied upon by a State considering a response” since the “robustness of permissible self-help responses grows commensurately with the seriousness of the breach.”¹¹¹ For example, a state should be more confident in its attribution when it responds with armed force to a cyber attack on an air traffic control system that resulted in aircraft accidents and fatalities. The same should be expected if it were to suffer an attack on the underground pump controllers for an underground rail system that resulted in major flooding and destruction of its infrastructure. If a state were to suffer a denial of service attack on the website of a regulatory agency that issues permits for hunting and fishing, however, principles of necessity and proportionality dictate that the victim state would only be permitted to respond with something\n¹¹⁰ Professors Christian Payne and Lorraine Finlay have proposed a standard of proof tied to the victim’s response, but they have failed to provide much detail other than suggesting victim states that “pursue peaceful, legal processes” for resolving disputes related to cyber operations should “have the benefit of eschewing stringent attribution tests normally required.” Payne &amp; Finlay, supra note 5, at 567. In such cases, they suggest strict liability for those states that the victim state believes to be the host states for the attack. Id. at 566–67. They do not discuss the standard of proof necessary to undertake countermeasures and argue that the “effective control” standard is required for self-defense measures. Id.; see also infra note 132 and accompanying text (discussing the “effective control” standard).\n¹¹¹ Tallinn Manual 2.0, supra note 1, at 82 (citing Oil Platforms, 2003 I.C.J. at ¶ 67 (separate opinion of Judge Higgins)).\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202\nLefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n26\nbelow the use of force, such as committing a violation of a trade or tax treaty between the two states.¹¹²\nUnder a shifting standard of proof for attributional claims, a state could respond to the first two examples with countermeasures if it perhaps only had probable cause that a given state had conducted the attacks. After acquiring evidence to prove its attributional claim at a higher standard of proof, such as clear-and-convincing evidence, a state could respond with armed force if it were to conclude that such force would be proportional and necessary to repel the attack or later attacks.¹¹³ This shifting standard of proof does not change the ultimate severity ceiling of the response available to the victim state, which is still tied to the underlying breach and governed by principles of proportionality and necessity; rather, it adapts the severity of the response to the standard of proof that the victim state is able to meet at any given point.¹¹⁴ This would allow victim states to respond—at least in some fashion—more quickly, and thereby more effectively, to offensive cyber operations than if a higher evidentiary threshold were required uniformly among all types of responses. Victim states, of course, could still increase the severity of their responses as needed to force the attacking state back into compliance with its international obligations, so long as the certainty in the attacker’s identity correspondingly increased.\nAdmittedly, such a standard might result in more severe and more frequent state responses against less sophisticated actors—who lack the ability to hide the evidence that leads to their identity—than sophisticated actors. But this is no different than any other system that requires evidentiary burdens to be met before responsive measures can be taken: even in domestic criminal\n¹¹² See infra note 113.\n¹¹³ International Governmental Group of Experts, Tallinn Manual on the International Law Applicable to Cyber Warfare 61 (Michael N.
