Further, and more importantly, the proposed evidentiary framework will create opportunities for states to take measures against actors whose sophistication in hiding their identity would, under a more exacting standard of proof, leave victims without any recourse time and time again.\nPart II further explores how evaluations of such evidence could be more publicly accountable by allowing states to submit their claims to a neutral body that would provide an attributional assessment of the offensive cyber operation, including a forensic report and a confidence judgment as to the culprit. It also examines how such a body could contribute to the creation of international norms—and, eventually, customary international law—that integrate this sliding-scale evidentiary framework and which make it clear what standard of proof a state should have to meet before responding with the use of force or countermeasures. In this way, the body could create a platform through which states could better define customary international law, even where attempts to build positive international law have stalled or failed.^^\n## D. Frameworks for Assessing State Responsibility for Cyber Operations\nIn contrast with standards of proof, principles of state responsibility are far better defined under international law, thanks to the ICJ's jurisprudence and the International Law Commission's (\"ILC\") Articles on State Responsibility. As a result, the second Tallinn Manual provides far more guidance about principles of state responsibility as they relate to cyber operations, beginning with Tallinn Rule 14's threshold^^: \"A State bears international responsibility for a cyber-related act\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202\nLefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n28\nthat is attributable to the State and that constitutes a breach of an international legal obligation.”¹¹⁷ Rules 15–18 particularize this requirement by adapting it to common situations, with each rule further attenuating the relation from the responsible state. Rule 15 indicates that states are responsible for cyber operations conducted by their own organs and individual representatives of the state who are authorized to exercise the governmental authority of the state.¹¹⁸ Rule 16 addresses situations in which a state places one of its organs at the disposal of another state. It indicates that cyber operations are attributable to the latter state so long as it is exercising government authority over the former state’s organ.¹¹⁹ Rule 17 deals with state control of non-state actors. It identifies that the state is responsible for those cyber operations committed by non-state actors that it directs, controls, or that the state acknowledges and adopts as its own, reflecting the concept of “effective control” articulated in the Nicaragua case.¹²⁰ Rule 18 deals with a state’s responsibility for the cyber operations of foreign states, concluding that one state bears responsibility for another’s cyber operation when, knowing of the act’s wrongful character, it either coerces, aids or assists, or directs and controls that state in the operation.¹²¹ As a result of the distributed nature of the Internet, the second Tallinn Manual took the view that geography is of little importance into inquiries of state responsibility.¹²² Instead, the inquiry is almost entirely grounded in the instruction received and control exercised by any given state.¹²³\n¹¹⁷ Tallinn Manual 2.0, supra note 1, at 84. The language “breach of an international legal obligation” is particularly important, since it does not include activities that are either unregulated by international law, such as cyber espionage and related intelligence gathering, or are expressly permitted, such as suspension of international cyber communication services within its territory. This would, at a minimum, require geographic diversity from each of the sectors represented and strict transparency in both its governance and evaluation methodologies and procedures.¹⁴³ As RAND puts it, with no international norms to rely upon at present, the Consortium can only derive its legitimacy over time from “the reputation and credibility gained from the technical expertise of its diverse global membership and its commitment to objectivity and transparency in its attribution findings.”¹⁴⁴\nTo deliver on the promise of providing more reliable and transparent attributional assessments than what states have offered to date, the Consortium would need to include formalized conditions that trigger its review, standardized processes for evidence collection and assessment, attribution-confidence standards, procedures for notification and publication of results, and standardized procedures to assess the severity and sophistication of offensive operations.¹⁴⁵ Indeed, standardization and transparency are two crucial elements missing from the current diffuse attribution regime. Filling the Evidentiary Gap and Building International Norms\nEven if the Consortium did not grant every investigation request it received, it still would have the potential to shift international norms toward stricter and more uniform standards of proof for attribution claims, paving the way for the sliding-scale evidentiary framework proposed in Part I. Further, in the investigations it would accept, its technical capabilities could still help to fill the evidentiary gap that states face in justifying countermeasures or self-defense, especially where the victim state’s technical capabilities are lacking.\nTo the extent that states are able to point to an independent body’s declassified cyber forensic investigation, a state’s justification for countermeasures would be built on firmer factual ground than if it only had its classified intelligence to rely upon. With a reduced ability to hide behind a claim of pretextual or false accusation, states might exercise more caution in conducting offensive cyber operations or might restrict themselves to low-level uses of force so as not to draw attention of the Consortium.¹⁵⁹ This is true whether or not key players in the international community choose to submit a case to the Consortium. One may expect that the United States, China, Israel, or Russia may at first feel more comfortable relying upon the technical sophistication of their own intelligence communities to reliably identify culprits and might reject opening up the process to an independent body. Challenges Ahead\nDespite the promise an independent non-governmental attribution body like the Consortium holds for building international norms, challenges remain for the Consortium’s effective execution. If independence is a key feature, from what sources could it responsibly derive funding? How will such a body prioritize its investigations and how will it deliver results quickly enough to meet the need for timely response that victim states will face? Further, without traditional sources of intelligence at hand, how will such a body meet the need to connect an operator’s activity with state direction and control in the case of state-sponsored attacks?\nRAND suggests initial funding from philanthropic sources and the inclusion of a charter mandate to seek funding from the United Nations at a later point.¹⁶⁶ RAND also points to the possibility of funding from cybersecurity and information technology companies that operate and defend much of the infrastructure upon which attacks are launched.¹⁶⁷ This might not be so far-fetched: if the Consortium were able to build a strong reputation in the international community,\n¹⁶⁴ Deeks, supra note 163.\n¹⁶⁵ See supra note 115.\n¹⁶⁶ Davis et al., RAND Corp., supra note 51, at 44.\n¹⁶⁷ Id. at 45.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202\nLefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n41\nparticipation might be a badge of honor for private sector firms, translating to increased business opportunities.\nIf it could be done transparently, this Note suggests another solution: the Consortium might even charge clients fees for attribution services, in accordance with their ability to pay, basing its schedule off of the United Nations’ scale of assessments for the apportionment of its expenses.¹⁶⁸ Admittedly, this might introduce risks to its neutrality if the organization appears to demonstrate something akin to customer loyalty. If any attribution body were to accept fees for its services to offset its costs, its revenue streams would need to be diversified enough to prevent reliance on fees from any particular state, region, or global bloc.\nDeveloping prioritization policies may best be left to the discretion of the Consortium, given the variety of effects cyber attacks produce and the difficulty in organizing attacks by their severity. For example, the Consortium might be forced to choose between investigating a cyber attack that resulted in an explosion that killed tens of people or a ransomware attack that paralyzed the state’s ability to provide key services and cost its citizens and businesses hundreds of millions of dollars and maybe, indirectly, loss of life.¹⁶⁹ In this case, one might suggest investigating the former first, since the victim state in that case would have suffered an armed attack under the effects test¹⁷⁰ and would have the right to respond in self-defense, if such measures were necessary to prevent future attacks.¹⁷¹ However, one can imagine murkier cases where the severity might be tied to the degree of harm suffered by the victim. The Value of a Sliding-Scale Attribution Standard\nThe absence of a standard of proof in these matters may be surprising, but it is likely—at least in part—a reflection of the reluctance among nations to share closely guarded intelligence methods on a global stage in front of ally and adversary alike.¹⁰⁸ There is little doubt, however, that developing international norms to establish a standard of proof for attributional claims before undertaking countermeasures or self-defense measures would force states to exercise restraint in using these tools. One would hope that such restraint could help prevent conflicts from escalating or even spilling over into wrongly accused states that had no previous role in a particular conflict.¹⁰⁹ Problems arise, though, in determining how high such a standard should be for cyber operations, given the difficulty many states face in being able to make an attributional claim with a high degree of confidence in a short amount of time. Challenges Ahead\nDespite the promise an independent non-governmental attribution body like the Consortium holds for building international norms, challenges remain for the Consortium’s effective execution. If independence is a key feature, from what sources could it responsibly derive funding? How will such a body prioritize its investigations and how will it deliver results quickly enough to meet the need for timely response that victim states will face? Further, without traditional sources of intelligence at hand, how will such a body meet the need to connect an operator’s activity with state direction and control in the case of state-sponsored attacks?\nRAND suggests initial funding from philanthropic sources and the inclusion of a charter mandate to seek funding from the United Nations at a later point.¹⁶⁶ RAND also points to the possibility of funding from cybersecurity and information technology companies that operate and defend much of the infrastructure upon which attacks are launched.¹⁶⁷ This might not be so far-fetched: if the Consortium were able to build a strong reputation in the international community,\n¹⁶⁴ Deeks, supra note 163.\n¹⁶⁵ See supra note 115.\n¹⁶⁶ Davis et al., RAND Corp., supra note 51, at 44.\n¹⁶⁷ Id. at 45.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202\nLefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n\nIf it could be done transparently, this Note suggests another solution: the Consortium might even charge clients fees for attribution services, in accordance with their ability to pay, basing its schedule off of the United Nations’ scale of assessments for the apportionment of its expenses.¹⁶⁸ Admittedly, this might introduce risks to its neutrality if the organization appears to demonstrate something akin to customer loyalty. If any attribution body were to accept fees for its services to offset its costs, its revenue streams would need to be diversified enough to prevent reliance on fees from any particular state, region, or global bloc.\nDeveloping prioritization policies may best be left to the discretion of the Consortium, given the variety of effects cyber attacks produce and the difficulty in organizing attacks by their severity. For example, the Consortium might be forced to choose between investigating a cyber attack that resulted in an explosion that killed tens of people or a ransomware attack that paralyzed the state’s ability to provide key services and cost its citizens and businesses hundreds of millions of dollars and maybe, indirectly, loss of life.¹⁶⁹ In this case, one might suggest investigating the former first, since the victim state in that case would have suffered an armed attack under the effects test¹⁷⁰ and would have the right to respond in self-defense, if such measures were necessary to prevent future attacks.¹⁷¹ However, one can imagine murkier cases where the severity might be tied to the degree of harm suffered by the victim.     "# CRACKING ATTRIBUTION: MOVING INTERNATIONAL NORMS FORWARD\n\nJoshua Lefebvre\n\nThis Note addresses how international law can meet the challenge of reliably and transparently identifying the actor responsible for a cyber attack, a feature of the cyber landscape referred to as the “attribution problem.” It examines the potential for customary international law to define evidentiary standards for evaluating claims of a cyber attacker’s identity, standards which would have to be met before a state victim could retaliate. Such a framework would replace the malleable and opaque ad hoc determinations of responsibility that states currently undertake in both the conventional force and the cyber contexts alike. To this end, this Note introduces a sliding-scale evidentiary standard that adapts to the—often limited—availability of evidence and short amount of time a victim might have to respond to cyber attacks.\n\nThis Note analogizes to attribution problems faced by the international community in the past, such as piracy and privateering on the eighteenth century’s high seas, to demonstrate that the legal problems posed by cyber capabilities are not unfamiliar. But the ubiquity of cyber capabilities and diffuse nature of the cyber landscape mean that the solution must be different. This Note demonstrates that a newly proposed non-governmental attribution body, structured like a tribunal, could meet the tremendous need many victims face in gathering the evidence to overcome the attribution problem inherent to cyberspace. Such a body, this Note argues, provides the best launchpad for developing the international norms—and, eventually, the customary international law—needed to build evidentiary standards in the cyber context.\n\nINTRODUCTION ... 1\n\nI.     "# INTRODUCTION\n\nEach year, state and non-state cyber capabilities increase in sophistication while attack surfaces widen, and yet, international law has not kept pace. Treaties dealing directly with cyber operations are scarce in number and limited in scope.¹ State cyber practices are held close to the chest and, although their publicly available expressions are increasing, there are still too few to constitute well-defined norms to develop comprehensive customary international law.² While it at least seems clear today that existing principles of international law apply in cyberspace,³ states—perhaps as a result of their own strategic caution⁴—have, at present, left to the academy and non-governmental bodies much of the task of determining how such principles apply.⁵ Against this hazy legal backdrop, states and non-state actors alike have wasted no time in deploying cyber attacks and exploitations of ever more destructive and exploitative power. In June 2017, according to the U.S. government, the Russian military launched “the most destructive and costly cyber attack in history,” using ransomware dubbed “NotPetya” to cause billions of dollars in damage across Europe, the Americas, and Asia.⁶ Just two months later, in August 2017, a petrochemical plant in Saudi Arabia suffered a cyber attack that was designed to trigger an explosion that likely\n\n¹ Introduction to International Governmental Group of Experts, Tallinn Manual 2.0 on the International Law Applicable to Cyber Operations 3 (Michael N. But the limitations of cyber defensive and investigative capabilities can and do pose obstacles to the application of international law. Principally, they foreground the question of how a state could respond lawfully under international law if it does not know against whom it should respond. Conventional Parallels\n\nThe difficulty in linking attacks to the identity of the attacker is not a new problem for international law: states have struggled with making such determinations for centuries. This is true where another state has been the attacker, where a non-state actor acting under its own direction has been the attacker, and where state proxies acting under the direction of a sponsoring state have been the source of the attacks. Some commentators have drawn parallels between today’s challenges in policing cyberspace to those created by the state use of privateers on the high seas in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.²⁴ Florian Egloff notes how both the high seas through that period and cyberspace involve a range of actors, each with varying degrees of direction and control from a sponsoring state.²⁵ Between these two different eras and environments, the parallels between state actors, semi-state actors, and non-state actors can be readily drawn: respectively, consider the similarities between formal navies and cyber military units, privateers and today’s “patriotic hackers,”²⁶ or even pirates and most modern cybercriminals or cybercrime organizations.²⁷\n\n²³ See infra note 66.\n\n²⁴ Florian Egloff, Cybersecurity and the Age of Privateering, in Understanding Cyber Conflict: 14 Analogies 231, (George Perkovich &amp; Ariel E.     "Lefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n8\n\nSimilar to attackers in cyberspace, privateers were able to shift their identity and locale with ease, creating ambiguity around the identity of the sponsoring state or a question of whether there was any sponsor state at all.²⁸ This ambiguity provided plausible deniability to states for violence carried out through privateering. In large part, it is not unlike that provided to modern states by “patriotic hackers” or other non-state actors in cyberspace who act with impunity in a harboring state, if not the state’s explicit sponsorship.²⁹ To deal with the difficulties arising out of this ambiguity, state practice led to expectations—and, eventually, customary international law—that privateers would post their true flags before firing a shot from across the bow in order to seize another ship for search, despite allowing false flags to be flown while chasing a vessel.³⁰ While this helped to mitigate the attribution difficulties that arose, they were not entirely resolved until privateering fell out of use after it was abolished by multilateral treaty in 1856.³¹\n\nMore modern comparisons are often drawn to the Cold War, where attribution and causality issues frequently arose in the context of Article 2(4) of the U.N.     "Lefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n9\n\nconflict was waged through proxies, it was difficult to develop international consensus about the relevant facts on such basic issues as what occurred and on whose behalf, let alone consensus about jus ad bellum responsibility or justification.”³⁴\n\nIn some ways, of course, cyber attacks and exploitations present categorically different and more significant technical challenges in determining attribution when compared to physical attacks carried out during the Cold War, a chemical weapons attack, or the actions of privateers through the nineteenth century.³⁵ The parallels, however, highlight the international legal problems posed when the identity of an attacker is uncertain. While technical attribution capabilities are increasing for many states, including the United States, the identification of the machine or machines used in carrying out the attack, their operators, or even the geographic locations of the machines and their operators is not always enough when making a determination of state responsibility.³⁶ Yet the stakes are high. If the injured state responds to a wrongful act under international law³⁷ with a countermeasure aimed at a wrongly accused state, then the injured state has then committed an internationally wrongful act by engaging in countermeasures against an innocent state.³⁸ Simply put, the international legal framework currently in place for responding to uses of force, armed attacks, and other breaches of international obligations cannot function properly without reliable attributional assessments, regardless of whether the unlawful action occurs in the context of a cyber or a traditional physical operation.³⁹\n\n³⁴ Id.\n\n³⁵ See Banks, supra note 2, at 1493 (describing some of the technical challenges posed by cyber attacks and exploitations).\n\n³⁶ Banks, supra note 2, at 1502. The Factual Challenge of Attribution\n\nAttribution of interstate cyber operations—like operations in the conventional kinetic context—can be broken down into two components: (1) the identity of the individual operators who carried out the operation; and (2) the relationship those operators have, if any, to any given state.⁴⁰ These two components comprise factual inquiries, of course, into what machines were used to carry out an attack, who operated them, and who directed or controlled those operators for purposes of the operation.\n\nAt the most basic level, an offensive cyber operation involves one or more individuals, often acting remotely, who interfaces with one or more computers or entire networks—usually by means of programming code—in order to gain access to the targeted systems through hardware or software security vulnerabilities or through fraudulent credentials. Once the operation’s conductors have gained access to the desired system, they attempt to take advantage of the system to plant code, known as malware,⁴¹ that will destroy or degrade the intruded system, exfiltrate information from the system, or both.⁴²\n\nCyber operations pose significant and unique challenges in the evidentiary context as it relates to both the identity of the operator and attribution to a state. This is in part because the operations are “opaque to public view, technically very complex and likely to emerge piecemeal,” unlike conventional kinetic attacks, which are visible and “can be and often are broadcast widely, immediately, and understandably [and, further, the] common experience [of such attacks] makes\n\n⁴⁰ See Military and Paramilitary Activities in and Against Nicaragua (Nicar. v. U.S.), Judgment, 1986 I.C.J. Rep. 14, ¶ 57 (June 27) (“The occurrence of the act itself may however have been shrouded in secrecy. In the latter case, the Court has had to endeavour first to establish what actually happened, before entering on the next stage of considering whether the act (if proven) was imputable to the State to which it has been attributed.”); Yeager v. Islamic Republic of Iran, 17 Iran-U.S. Cl. Trib.     "Lefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n13\n\nand exploitation malware, which can give a cyber forensic analyst hints as to the time zone or work patterns of the attacker.⁵⁶ Natural language strings left behind in malware code to communicate with other offensive operators working on the same attack or exploitation can also provide critical clues, such as information about the native language or national origin of the operators.⁵⁷ Cyber operators sometimes re-use malware code, passwords or encryption keys, and highly sophisticated exploits⁵⁸ in a way that allows malware to be grouped into families. Once the work of these operators has been compiled into these groups, their errors and the evidence of their identity begin to stack up across operations and malware toolkits, leading forensic investigators to more easily identify them.⁵⁹ Lastly, the identity of targets themselves might provide clues as to whom the attacker might be, since victim-targeting patterns might assist forensic analysts in building a more accurate attacker profile.⁶⁰\n\nBut intermediate-to-advanced cyber actors do not proceed unaware of these investigative tactics.     "Lefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n18\n\nThe law of state responsibility does not set forth explicit burdens or standards of proof for making a determination about legal attribution. In this context, a State acts as its own judge of the facts and may make a unilateral determination with respect to attribution of a cyber operation to another State. Absolute certainty is not—and cannot be—required. Instead, international law generally requires that States act reasonably under the circumstances when they gather information and draw conclusions based on that information.78\n\nThe IGE understands this “reasonableness” standard as involving an examination of whether states have considered, among other factors, the reliability, quantum, directness, nature, and specificity of the relevant information available to the injured state in light of attendant circumstances and the importance of the right involved.79 While these factors are fairly malleable, the method is not dissimilar from the “ad hoc” way in which states evaluate factual claims in the conventional force context.80\n\nAs to whether the reasonableness standard includes the obligation to publicly disclose the evidence on which an attribution claim has been made, the IGE was of the opinion that there is not enough state practice or *opinio juris* to evidence such a requirement under customary international law.81 This insufficiency is, in large part, a result of the highly classified nature of cyber capabilities, whether used offensively, defensively, or as part of a forensic investigation.82 Conceivably, this could change as more forensic analysis of cyber operations is conducted by\n\n78 Brian J. Egan, Remarks on International Law and Stability in Cyberspace at Berkeley Law School (Nov. 10, 2016), https://www.law.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/egan-talk-transcript-111016.pdf. It is worth noting that Egan’s statement may be a step forward, but it does not amount to much. No state could possibly expect absolute certainty given the difficulties surrounding attribution of offensive cyber operations. By settling on a requirement of “reasonableness,” the statement begs the question it is trying to answer, since such “reasonableness” can run the gamut in terms of what it could require.\n\n79 Tallinn Manual 2.0, supra note 1, at 82 (noting, in addition, that the available information considered need not be restricted to technical intelligence if it can be supplemented with highly reliable human intelligence).\n\n80 See Jules Lobel, Colloquy, The Use of Force to Respond to Terrorist Attacks: The Bombing of Sudan and Afghanistan, 24 Yale J.     "Lefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n20\n\n## 2. Does International Law Already Contain a General Attribution Standard?\n\nDrawing from the above, it would seem that, at present, no state under international law carries an obligation of publicly proving its attributional claim by revealing the available evidence, whether that be in the cyber or conventional force context.⁸⁸ Nor does it seem that states carry a well-defined burden under international law related to the quality or amount of evidence used in proving an attributional claim before undertaking acts of self-defense or countermeasures against the accused state.⁸⁹ Further, strikingly few commentators have even addressed the issue of evidentiary burdens under international law. But despite the IGE’s findings and the claims that states like the United States have made about (non-)obligations under international law, there is a contingent of those few who have argued the contrary. Such commentators claim that sufficient state practice exists to locate the standard of proof required of attribution claims.⁹⁰\n\nProfessor Mary Ellen O’Connell has argued that, at least in situations in which states are justifying the use of force under Article 51’s self-defense provision, state practice and the decisions of international courts and tribunals support a “clear and convincing” standard in evaluating evidence.⁹¹ She claims that “the international authority for the standard consists of several\n\n⁸⁸ See also Banks, supra note 2, at 1499 (“Applying the Rules on State Responsibility and attribution compiled in Tallinn 2.0, there is no burden of proof or requirement that there exists definitive information on attribution. Charter); see Robin Geiß &amp; Henning Lahmann, Freedom and Security in Cyberspace: Shifting the Focus Away From Military Responses Towards Non-Forcible Countermeasures and Collective Threat-Prevention, in Peacetime Regime for State Activities in Cyberspace: International Law, International Relations and Diplomacy 621, 624 (Katharina Ziolkowski ed., 2013) (arguing that a “clear and convincing” standard has been applied in ICJ decisions governing state responsibility). Professor O’Connell’s paper arguing that a clear-and-convincing has proven the most influential out of those few that argue in favor of its existence, and so my argument places the most emphasis on defusing the claim as she describes it.\n\n⁹¹ O’Connell, supra note 68, at 21–28; see Geiß &amp; Lahmann, Freedom and Security in Cyberspace: Shifting the Focus Away From Military Responses Towards Non-Forcible Countermeasures and Collective Threat-Prevention, in Peacetime Regime for State Activities in Cyberspace: International Law, International Relations and Diplomacy, supra note 90, at 624 (arguing that the “clear and convincing” standard was applied by the ICJ implicitly in the its decisions in the Nicaragua case, Oil Platforms case, and Armed Activities case).\n\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202",

Bush, and the 1998 bombing of Sudan and Afghanistan after attacks on U.S. embassies in Nairobi and Dar es Salaam.⁹² Professor O’Connell’s evidence for such claims raises questions, however, about whether such an obligation truly exists under international law.\n\nFirst, while she cites examples of state practice of injured states using language indicating that they are in possession of “clear,” “compelling,” or “convincing” evidence of having suffered an internationally wrongful act at the hand of a particular state, there is no indication that this is done out of a sense of legal obligation.⁹³ State practice on its own is insufficient to establish customary international law; it is only when it is done out of a sense of legal obligation, or *opinio juris*, that it can be considered customary international law.     "Lefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n22\n\nWhile Professor O'Connell and other commentators cite implicit standards of proof in the International Court of Justice’s (“ICJ”) rulings, among other international courts and tribunals,⁹⁴ there is no indication that the ICJ’s procedural standards have any bearing on claims that appear in front of other bodies or that such standards reflect customary international law. The ICJ’s opinion in the Nicaragua case, which these commentators claim supports a “clear and convincing” standard,⁹⁵ suggests that its standard of proof derives from Article 53 of the Statute on the International Court of Justice,⁹⁶ which does not purport to have impact outside of the operations of that court.⁹⁷ Further, O'Connell’s evidence that the ICJ uses a “clear and compelling” standard of proof is limited to consistent references to whether evidence is “sufficient” or “insufficient.”⁹⁸ But declaring whether a particular amount of evidence is sufficient is distinct from whether it is necessary. Indeed, the ICJ’s opinion merely points to the fact that evidence has met or surpassed the necessary standard of proof; it does not indicate what that standard is. While the ICJ does mention that its findings of fact should be based upon “convincing” evidence, it includes a caveat: that it should only do so to the extent that “the nature of the case permits.”⁹⁹ This seems to suggest a shifting standard of proof, determined on the basis of the availability and nature of the facts.\n\nProfessors Robin Geiß and Henning Lahmann make similar claims about the standard of proof in the Oil Platforms and Armed Attacks cases, claiming the ICJ uses an implicit “clear and convincing” standard.¹⁰⁰ But again, the ICJ in the Oil Platforms case merely refers to the\n\n⁹⁴ O'Connell, supra note 68, at 23–24; Geiß &amp; Lahmann, supra note 90, at 624; see also Marco Roscini, Symposium, Evidentiary Issues Related to Cyber Operations, 50 Tex. The Value of a Sliding-Scale Attribution Standard\n\nThe absence of a standard of proof in these matters may be surprising, but it is likely—at least in part—a reflection of the reluctance among nations to share closely guarded intelligence methods on a global stage in front of ally and adversary alike.¹⁰⁸ There is little doubt, however, that developing international norms to establish a standard of proof for attributional claims before undertaking countermeasures or self-defense measures would force states to exercise restraint in using these tools. One would hope that such restraint could help prevent conflicts from escalating or even spilling over into wrongly accused states that had no previous role in a particular conflict.¹⁰⁹ Problems arise, though, in determining how high such a standard should be for cyber operations, given the difficulty many states face in being able to make an attributional claim with a high degree of confidence in a short amount of time. Such difficulty might be resolved by applying a shifting standard of proof, not unlike what the ICJ appears to employ based upon “the nature of the case.”\n\nA standard of proof tied to the anticipated severity of the victim state’s response rather than to the severity of the underlying breach might meet the goals of timely response while adapting to the lower quality and quantity of evidence available to the victim state shortly after suffering an offensive cyber operation.¹¹⁰ For example, the victim state might only need to find on the balance of evidence that a particular state is responsible for an offensive cyber operation if deploying countermeasures, such as the violation of a treaty between the victim and aggressor states, but it may need clear-and-convincing evidence to respond with a use of armed force. This proposal falls in line with the second Tallinn Manual’s suggestion that “the greater the underlying breach . . . the greater the confidence ought to be in the evidence relied upon by a State considering a response” since the “robustness of permissible self-help responses grows commensurately with the seriousness of the breach.”¹¹¹ For example, a state should be more confident in its attribution when it responds with armed force to a cyber attack on an air traffic control system that resulted in aircraft accidents and fatalities. The same should be expected if it were to suffer an attack on the underground pump controllers for an underground rail system that resulted in major flooding and destruction of its infrastructure.     "Lefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n28\n\nthat is attributable to the State and that constitutes a breach of an international legal obligation.”¹¹⁷ Rules 15–18 particularize this requirement by adapting it to common situations, with each rule further attenuating the relation from the responsible state. Rule 15 indicates that states are responsible for cyber operations conducted by their own organs and individual representatives of the state who are authorized to exercise the governmental authority of the state.¹¹⁸ Rule 16 addresses situations in which a state places one of its organs at the disposal of another state. It indicates that cyber operations are attributable to the latter state so long as it is exercising government authority over the former state’s organ.¹¹⁹ Rule 17 deals with state control of non-state actors.     "Lefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n29\n\nAlternatively, a victim state could find that another state has violated principles of due diligence by not taking reasonable measures to prevent its territory or cyber infrastructure under its governmental control from being used by others to commit offensive cyber operations that either “affect the rights of or produce adverse consequences for other States,” an inquiry that necessarily involves geography.¹²⁴ In this case, which is governed by Rules 6–7 of the second Tallinn Manual, states would not be held responsible for such offensive cyber operations, but they would be held in breach of their obligation to exercise due diligence.¹²⁵ If the claim can be satisfactorily proven, this would allow the victim state to enact countermeasures in order to bring the negligent state back into compliance with its international obligations.¹²⁶\n\nWith the exception of Rules 6–7, each rule provides a separate avenue by which to attribute responsibility for a cyber operation to a particular state. Building a Private Body for a Public Good\n\nIn 2017, researchers at the RAND Corporation published a white paper proposing the creation of an attributional organization that would exclude states from its management and operation, referring to the proposed body as the “Global Cyber Attribution Consortium” (“the Consortium”).¹⁴⁰ Instead of states, RAND proposes that the body be managed and operated by cyberspace legal and policy experts, international policy experts from academia and research organizations, and technical experts from academia as well as cybersecurity and information technology companies.¹⁴¹ RAND recognizes that these actors are not immune to politicization: they may face pressures from their home markets or states of incorporation, or they may inherently possess strong national loyalties. But such a body would at least be further removed from state political interests and face more political accountability at the international level, to the extent that the companies and research organizations involved conduct global operations.¹⁴² Most\n\n¹³⁸ Davis et al., RAND Corp., supra note 51, at 31; see Efrony, supra note 133 (“None of the experts should be simultaneously employed by governmental institutions to avoid even the appearance of conflicts of interest.”).\n¹³⁹ Davis et al., RAND Corp., supra note 51, at 31.\n¹⁴⁰ Id at 27, 33. To be clear, by using the term “attribution organization,” the suggestion is that the organization engages exclusively in attributional assessments. Unlike the proposals suggested by Microsoft and the Atlantic Council, it has no enforcement function. See Charney, Microsoft Corp., supra note 12, at 11; Jason Healey, et al., Atlantic Council, Confidence-Building Measures in Cyberspace: A Multistakeholder Approach for Stability and Security 10 (2014).\n¹⁴¹ Davis et al., RAND Corp., supra note 51, at 29; see also Efrony, supra note 133 (supporting the idea of excluding states from a global attribution body).\n¹⁴² Admittedly, “global operations” does not mean such operations will be equal among all states. One might argue that states with more sophisticated technology sectors could have more influence over the Consortium than states with less sophisticated technology sectors, since such countries will likely have stronger ties to members of the Consortium. But given the wide network of global interests and partnerships that states with sophisticated technology sectors have, which often tie them to states with smaller technology sectors, it is unlikely that the Consortium could or would privilege states along this line. The nature of the organization’s work requires not only a better reputation for neutrality than what could be accomplished with an intergovernmental organization, but an incredibly strong reputation for neutrality and expertise.     "Lefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n36\n\nMore complex issues arise when deciding which of multiple states should have standing to bring a claim. Consider, for example, a scenario in which an actor conducts an offensive cyber operation against a company incorporated in the United States with its principal place of business in the United States. Suppose, however, that the company also has offices in Beijing and the offensive cyber operation was conducted exclusively against the company’s servers in Beijing, resulting in significant physical destruction of company property and the death of one or more U.S. nationals. On one hand, one might think that the United States is the victim state, since a kinetic attack was conducted against its nationals and their property.¹⁵⁶ However, if the culprit is a foreign state, China would have suffered an armed attack and a violation of its territorial integrity.¹⁵⁷ But depending on the circumstances surrounding the attack, there might even be reasonable suspicion that China itself is the culprit. Which state should be able to bring the episode to the Consortium? The answer, at least on these facts, seems to be that both states should have standing to bring the investigation request. But even if both parties have standing, should both enjoy the right to publicize the result? If the United States wanted to publicize the result, but China did not, should China retain a veto over the United States’ decision to publicize? The answer to that question is unclear, but it demonstrates that standing to bring an investigation request may not necessarily track with the right to publicize the result. Filling the Evidentiary Gap and Building International Norms\n\nEven if the Consortium did not grant every investigation request it received, it still would have the potential to shift international norms toward stricter and more uniform standards of proof for attribution claims, paving the way for the sliding-scale evidentiary framework proposed in Part I. Further, in the investigations it would accept, its technical capabilities could still help to fill the evidentiary gap that states face in justifying countermeasures or self-defense, especially where the victim state’s technical capabilities are lacking.\n\nTo the extent that states are able to point to an independent body’s declassified cyber forensic investigation, a state’s justification for countermeasures would be built on firmer factual ground than if it only had its classified intelligence to rely upon. With a reduced ability to hide behind a claim of pretextual or false accusation, states might exercise more caution in conducting offensive cyber operations or might restrict themselves to low-level uses of force so as not to draw attention of the Consortium.¹⁵⁹ This is true whether or not key players in the international community choose to submit a case to the Consortium. One may expect that the United States, China, Israel, or Russia may at first feel more comfortable relying upon the technical sophistication of their own intelligence communities to reliably identify culprits and might reject opening up the process to an independent body. Challenges Ahead\n\nDespite the promise an independent non-governmental attribution body like the Consortium holds for building international norms, challenges remain for the Consortium’s effective execution. If independence is a key feature, from what sources could it responsibly derive funding? How will such a body prioritize its investigations and how will it deliver results quickly enough to meet the need for timely response that victim states will face? Further, without traditional sources of intelligence at hand, how will such a body meet the need to connect an operator’s activity with state direction and control in the case of state-sponsored attacks?\n\nRAND suggests initial funding from philanthropic sources and the inclusion of a charter mandate to seek funding from the United Nations at a later point.¹⁶⁶ RAND also points to the possibility of funding from cybersecurity and information technology companies that operate and defend much of the infrastructure upon which attacks are launched.¹⁶⁷ This might not be so far-fetched: if the Consortium were able to build a strong reputation in the international community,\n\n¹⁶⁴ Deeks, supra note 163.\n¹⁶⁵ See supra note 115.\n¹⁶⁶ Davis et al., RAND Corp., supra note 51, at 44.\n¹⁶⁷ Id. at 45.\n\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202",

    "Lefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n43\n\nWhile forensic analyses can assess the sophistication levels of threat actors and can support inferences about state involvement based on the sophistication of the attack, making state responsibility claims will be difficult, especially if states begin to contract out more and more offensive cyber operations to non-state actors.¹⁷³ Associating state control with offensive cyber operations is not impossible, however, and to date private cybersecurity firms have been able to find enough clues to make at least low- or medium-confidence assessments of state responsibility.     "Lefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n44\n\nNations in late 2017¹⁷⁶ and to the meeting of the World Economic Forum in Davos in 2018.¹⁷⁷ He argues that, just as the Fourth Geneva Convention contemplated an active role for the Red Cross, the international community must contemplate a similar role for tech companies:\n\n[P]rotection against nation-state cyberattacks requires the active assistance of technology companies. The tech sector plays a unique role as the internet's first responders, and we therefore should commit ourselves to collective action that will make the internet a safer place, affirming a role as a neutral Digital Switzerland that assists customers everywhere and retains the world's trust.¹⁷⁸\n\nSmith has gone to great lengths in an attempt to operationalize this principle, by leading the campaign to sign on more than thirty tech firms to the “Cybersecurity Tech Accord,” including Cisco, Dell, Facebook, FireEye, HP, Symantec, and Oracle.¹⁷⁹ The accord’s principles commit the signatories to supporting civil society, governments, and international organizations in advancing and building cybersecurity capacity to protect against offensive cyber operations, among other goals that would align with the driving principles behind organizing the Consortium.¹⁸⁰ While the accord is still young, its existence is a helpful indication of the tech sector’s thinking on these issues, and it suggests that the possibility of an investigative body like the Consortium is more greater than it appears on its face.\n\n¹⁷⁶ Brad Smith Takes His Call for a Digital Geneva Convention to the United Nations, Microsoft: Microsoft On the Issues (Nov. 7, 2017), https://blogs.microsoft.com/on-the-issues/2017/11/09/brad-smith-takes-call-digital-geneva-convention-united-nations/.\n¹⁷⁷ Sam Meredith, Microsoft Calls for ‘New Digital Geneva Convention’ after Spate of High-Profile Cyberattacks, CNBC (Jan. 26, 2018), https://www.cnbc.com/2018/01/26/microsoft-calls-for-new-digital-geneva-convention-after-spate-of-high-profile-cyberattacks.html\n¹⁷⁸ Brad Smith, The Need for a Digital Geneva Convention, Microsoft: Microsoft on the Issues (Feb. 14, 2017), https://blogs.microsoft.com/on-the-issues/2017/02/14/need-digital-geneva-convention/#sm.0001hkfw5aob5evwum620jqwsabzv.\n¹⁷⁹ David Sanger, Tech Firms Sign “Digital Geneva Accord” Not to Aid Governments in Cyberwar, N.Y. Times (April 17, 2018), https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/17/us/politics/tech-companies-cybersecurity-accord.html; About the Cybersecurity Tech Accord, Cybersecurity Tech Accord, https://cybertechaccord.org/about/ (last visited March 29, 2019).\n¹⁸⁰ Protecting Users and Customers Everywhere, Cybersecurity Tech Accords: Our Commitment, https://cybertechaccord.org/accord/ (last visited March 29, 2019).\n\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202",
    "Lefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n45\n\n# CONCLUSION\n\nChallenges dot the road ahead for progress on international norms in cyberspace. While multilateral treaties and international cooperation might be the preferred avenue to overcome them, current trends provide little hope for the success of such options. Despite this, the development of customary international law provides an opportunity to push forward in regulating state behavior surrounding cyberspace. This Note demonstrates how an attributional body like the Consortium stands to provide substantial benefit to the development of these norms by providing states with a transparent and independent mechanism upon which to build evidentiary standards, such as the sliding-scale evidentiary framework, to undergird countermeasures and acts of self-defense. In this way, the international community can make more consistent judgments about state action in response to offensive cyber operations. While this may provide less flexibility for states to act in the face of such operations than what is nearly guaranteed through today's system of opaque unilateral evidentiary assessments, such restrictions on state behavior would benefit the international community at large by increasing global stability. Further, adopting this Note's version of a sliding-scale approach to the standard of proof—one where the standard fluctuates based on the response a victim wishes to undertake—should accommodate the flexibility states need when attempting to respond to quickly to a cyber attack.\n\nBy offering both victim states and the accused the opportunity to obtain an independent, sophisticated, and quantifiable attributional assessment, a body like the Consortium could help alleviate the deterrence difficulties inherent in a low-confidence attribution landscape and reduce the risk that states escalate or begin conflicts with parties that have no relation to the conflict. Questions persist regarding sources of funding for the Consortium, its operational efficiency in light of the need for quick responses to severe offensive operations, and the remaining difficulty\n\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202",
    "Lefebvre\nCracking Attribution\n46\n\nof connecting cyber operators to state direction and control. But they are by no means insurmountable.\n\nWhatever the case, the world will not stand still in the cyber landscape. If international law is to be of any value in restricting dangerous state behavior in this arena, its development must push forward. States can still do their part to gradually advance international norms by responsibly conducting their own cyber practices and related behavior in an effort to shape customary international law. An independent non-governmental attributional body like the Consortium provides a powerful launchpad for them to do just that.\n\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3300202"
